Award.AwardTitle: Hormones, social dynamics, and variation in responses to inequity in social group settings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. The current project allows for a groundbreaking new way to study social behavior in intact, interacting social groups, both in captive and wild social groups, while collecting information on underlying biological mechanisms to these behaviors. Humans vary in how they respond when receiving less than expected (e.g. contrast) or less than a social partner (e.g., inequity). Inequity is almost ubiquitous in human society, and negative reactions to inequitable circumstances can exacerbate already bad outcomes. Thus, it is critical to better understand what causes humans to respond to negative outcomes, and what factors can exacerbate or, ideally, ameliorate, these reactions. Humans responses to violated expectations are influenced by both individual factors, such as personality, dominance, and hormone profiles, and social factors, such as societal norms, kinship, and relationship quality. One of the weaknesses of human studies is that these factors are often examined independently, with little regard for how social and individual contexts influence one another. Part of the challenge is practical, human societies involve so much complexity that it is nearly impossible to follow all of each individuals' relationships over an extended time period and to control all the circumstances that occur in freely acting social groups. Yet, such a socially typical paradigm is necessary to fully understand how individual differences and real-world group dynamics influence our decisions. This research will address this problem, examining decision-making in a socially relevant, group-level context in capuchin monkeys.

Capuchin monkeys are an ideal species in which to study this question. Like humans, capuchins are highly social, routinely cooperate, and systematically experience strong negative reactions to inequity. Yet, all previous studies on inequity in nonhuman primates have been conducted in captivity and the vast majority have relied on how individuals behave when in pairs separated from their social group. As a result, whether capuchins maintain their aversion to inequity in more social and ecologically relevant environment remains unknown. This research will examine response to inequity in intact social groups both at in captivity at Georgia State University and in the field in Iguazu Argentina, allowing the unprecedented opportunity to compare social decision-making in a controlled laboratory setting and in a real-world context. This research has two main goals. First, by implementing a novel, experimenter-free paradigm that allows for remote group testing, this research will investigate how social factors and group dynamics influence responses to inequity. Second, this study will examine the biological mechanisms mediating response to inequity within a social context. Recent research in humans has highlighted the importance of hormones in influencing decision-making behavior. However, again, these studies have been conducted outside of the context of a normal social environment. This research will integrate noninvasive measures of fecal hormone analyses to assess how individual differences in response to inequity may be mediated by hormone levels, or an interaction between hormones and social context, that will be insightful in uncovering the biological mechanisms driving individual differences in decision-making behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human behavior is highly context dependent. A complex set of social and individual factors can influence how humans act when making choices. Yet, the majority of studies on social decision-making in humans have been confined to laboratory settings. An assumption underlying these experiments is that the insights they provide can be extrapolated to the outside world, which may not be the case. In order to understand why we make certain social choices, and the factors that influence these choices, we need to examine decision-making in the real world. The overall goal of this project was to examine the underlying factors that influence variation in decision-making by studying social choices in a socially relevant context. To do this, we used capuchin monkeys, a highly intelligent and cooperative primate, as a tractable model. 

This postdoctoral fellowship had three main objectives. First, we examined the mechanisms that influence variation in social decision-making by assesing how oxytocin and testosterone mediate decision-making in capuchins. Second, we examined how capuchins respond to inequity in both in captivity and in the wild. Third, this fellowship provided professional development to the Benitez, allowing her to establish and co-direct a new field site on capuchin cognition and initiate an independent research program examining the evolution of cooperation and the mechanisms of social decision-making in primates.

Intellectual Merit: This project applies experimentally controlled paradigms, to understand how cooperative decisions are made, in socially relevant contexts, to determine why these decisions are adaptive. To do this, Benitez implemented two experimental paradigms, a feeder box (Fig 1a) and a bar pull paradigm (Fig 1b), to examine how capuchins make cooperative decisions within their social groups. Benitez found that capuchins change their decision-making behavior depending on food reward distribution (e.g., equitable vs. inequitable) and social context (e.g., alone or competing against a rival group). Preliminary results show that capuchins exhibit similar behaviors as humans, cooperating about half the time for inequitable outcomes in absence of competition, but increasing that rate of cooperation to 90% of the time when threatened by a rival group. Results from this study highlight the importance of understanding social context on decision-making and suggest that competition might be a driving factor in high-levels of cooperation in social animals. Current research is examining whether these results hold in wild monkeys, in both Argentina (Fig 1c) and Costa Rica (Fig 1d), to further examine how social and ecological factors influence cooperative choices.

In addition, Benitez developed a method for analyzing testosterone and oxytocin in capuchins, providing some of the first evidence of the effects of competition on testosterone and affiliative social behavior on oxytocin in this species. Benitez found that within weeks of being introduced to novel females, testosterone levels increased in males, closely followed by changes in body mass and aggression, suggesting that males rapidly upregulate testosterone levels, and overall competitive ability, in response to challenges over mating opportunities. In addition, urinary oxytocin increased following both grooming and fur-rubbing, two affiliative behaviors important in maintaining social bonds (Benitez et al., 2018). By implementing these methods, Benitez found that oxytocin increased when rates of cooperation were the highest, suggesting that oxytocin plays an important role in mediating cooperation during conflict across the primate taxa.

Lastly, this fellowship opened the door to novel research examining social cognition, cooperation, and the neuroendocrine mechanisms of social choices. The findings that fur-rubbing increases oxytocin provides a novel method to naturally increase oxytocin by inducing fur-rubbing behavior, methods Benitez is implementing to examine the effect of oxytocin on cooperation. Benitez has established a new field site in Costa Rica, Capuchins de Taboga (Tinsley Johnson et al., 2020), for which she is co-director. There she is examining behavior and social cognition of wild white-faced capuchin monkeys. Furture research will examine whether white-faced capuchins are sensitive to inequity, and how competition influence social decision-making.

Broader Impacts: This fellowship provided invaluable training. Benitez has formed long-term collaborations with mentor Sarah Brosnan on the hormonal correlates of decision-making in captive capuchins and initiated an independent research program on experimental field cognition. Benitez and Brosnan have received two grants to continue their research on the mechanisms of cooperation in captivity (NSF SBE 1919305) and in the wild (Templeton World Charity Fund). Benitez will be starting a tenure track position at Emory in 2021.

Benitez actively mentors underrepresented students on research methods and professional development at both GSU and in Costa Rica. Benitez has trained 7 students and 5 assistants on hormone methods, which are now being implemented into their independent research on the relationship between hormones and social cognition. Benitez is an active participant in 500 Women Scientists, the Atlanta Science Festival, and has given several talks to school children.  In Costa Rica, Benitez has given bi-annual talks on topics regarding research methods and grant writing to faculty at UTN.
